message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is having absence seizures, which are characterized by 3 Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges on EEG. Ethosuximide is the first-line therapy for absence seizures in children. Lamotrigine is used for focal seizures or generalized tonic-clonic seizures, while Sodium valproate is used for many types of seizures but not specifically absence seizures. No pharmacotherapy at this time is not appropriate given the frequency and duration of the episodes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the spells and the EEG findings suggest that the boy has absence seizures. Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for treating absence seizures.

Ethosuximide is a first-line treatment for absence seizures. Lamotrigine and sodium valproate can also be used in some cases, but ethosuximide is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy at this time. No pharmacotherapy at this time is not a valid option as proper management is necessary to prevent further seizures and long-term consequences.
